"Republics decline into democracies and democracies degenerate into 
despotisms." ~ Aristotle 

"The more corrupt the state, the more numerous the laws." ~ Tacitus 

"Behind the ostensible government sits enthroned an invisible government 
owing no allegiance and acknowledging no responsibility to the people. " ~ 
Theodore Roosevelt 

“Government is not reason, it is not eloquence, it is force; like fire, a 
troublesome servant and a fearful master. Never for a moment should it be 
left to irresponsible action.” ~ George Washington 

"The spirit of resistance to government is so valuable on certain 
occasions, that I wish it to be always kept alive. It will often be 
exercised when wrong, but better so than not to be exercised at all. I like 
a little rebellion now and then." ~ Thomas Jefferson 

“Experience hath shewn, that even under the best forms (of government) 
those entrusted with power have, in time, and by slow operations, perverted 
it into tyranny.” ~ Thomas Jefferson 

“Fear is the foundation of most governments; but it is so sordid and brutal 
a passion, and renders men in whose breasts it predominates so stupid and 
miserable, that Americans will not be likely to approve of any political 
institution which is founded on it.” ~ John Adams (Were it so today) 

"The truth is that all men having power ought to be mistrusted." ~ James 
Madison 

“There are more instances of the abridgment of the freedom of the people by 
the gradual and silent encroachment of those in power, than by violent and 
sudden usurpation.” ~ James Madison 

"Resistance to tyrants is obedience to God." ~ Benjamin Franklin 

"Government, in it's last analysis, is organized force". ~ Woodrow Wilson 

"Government is a disease masquerading as it's own cure". ~ L. Neal Smith 

"Government in it's best state, is but a necessary evil, in it's worse 
state, an intolerable one." ~ Thomas Paine 

“A government that is big enough to give you all you want is big enough to 
take it all away.” ~ Barry Goldwater﻿

comments.text:
+DonCDXX Well, first of all, you are undoubtedly right at a general level. 
There is no one style that is going to be most effective with every type of 
audience. Fox News and the GOP have done very well with extreme rhetoric, 
especially. Glenn Beck's whole career is based on extreme speech.

That said, Elizabeth Warren does not lack for passion. I don't think very 
many people would say she does not make a passionate appeal. But she 
doesn't express a deep loathing for Obama, the way so many of his critics 
(including TYT) feel compelled to. She doesn't call him a war criminal. She 
doesn't accuse him of being a pawn of bankers. She doesn't say he is trying 
to destroy America. Those slurs might tickle the pleasure centers of people 
who hate Obama, but they will not be effective at convincing anyone else, 
and they will actively push away Obama supporters. There are a lot of 
people who voted for the president and who still like him quite a bit. If 
you want to reach those people, and Elizabeth Warren does, you don't start 
by calling the president the anti-christ. Instead, you make a strong, 
compelling, fact-based argument without the poison. 

She's showing us that it works very well, and as I said before, a lot of 
people (including TYT) could learn from her example.

comments.text:
+Hard Left Turn Wilson was an interventionist, he was determined to get us 
into that war somehow..  Even if Americans really had no stake in the 
European power-politics going on at the time... the US population was 
strongly anti-war (a tradition that seems lost on the current US 
population) and didn't see the point in getting involved.

If we allow the Germans to win WW1, then WW2 never happens.  And you do 
know that it was the British and French that were *by far* the preeminent 
imperial powers of the world; so why should we have spilled American blood 
and treasure to help the dominant imperialists??

Germany had almost no colonies, and we can't predict the future but why is 
everything anti-German??  If they win a war on two fronts in which they 
were outnumbered... they deserve to win without US intervention playing 
king-maker after years of stalemate in the West.

What happened near the end of WW1... and the abhorrent peace deal at 
Versailles directly set the fuse for a future WW2 which would prove more 
deadly.  The Versailles treaty was beyond unjust, especially considering 
the Germans were basically taking on all the imperial powers combined, and 
gave up zero ground.

Germans had the right to feel "stabbed in the back".  They had to pay for 
the entire war debts of both sides and they never gave up a single inch of 
their own territory.  That makes no sense.

The pretext to war was all posturing.  To solely blame the Germans was 
unfair.  And again, it led to WW2--->Holocaust.

And once again, Wilson himself said in 1919 that he had unwittingly "ruined 
my country" in that secret meeting on Jekyll Island a day or two before 
Christmas... by handing over the power to print currency to a handful of 
fatcat bankers.

Wilson was not a good president.  He may have meant well, and i think he 
probably did... but he used the Lusitania disingenuously to stir up pro-war 
feelings and he sold future generations down the river by letting *private 
banks lend money to the US government at interest*.

JFK knew the deal regarding the Federal Reserve, he tried to introduce a 
competing currency but alas... he was shot for trying to take on the 
banking monsters Wilson helped crown as our economic masters.

Good on JFK (the last honest truly US president IMO); bad on Wilson.  And i 
am not being partisan here, JFK was Democrat.

comments.text:
+mantonio121773 It sounds better because it is what you want to hear. In 
the ongoing farm bill amendment process, progressive champion Senator 
Bernie Sanders (I-VT) introduced an amendment that would guarantee states 
the right to pass and implement GMO labeling laws.  The statement of 
purpose for Sanders's amendment reads "to permit States to require that any 
food, beverage, or other edible product offered for sale have a label on 
indicating that the food, beverage, or other edible product contains a 
genetically engineered ingredient."  Companies like Monsanto have argued 
that states do not have the right to pass such laws, that only the federal 
government has that authority.  Sanders's amendment would eliminate that 
counterargument.
GMO labeling is very popular among the public--and, of course, not popular 
at all with Big Ag.  In a YouGov poll from two months ago, 82% thought GMO 
foods should be labeled, with just 9% opposed.
In what should come as no surprise because Congress listens more to 
industry than to public opinion, the amendment failed.  The vote count was 
27-71. Among the 27 supporters were 24 Democrats, 2 Independents, and 1 
lone Republican.

comments.text:
That makes no sense. Monsanto doesn't make food.  They sell seeds.  You 
want them to label every seed or...? 

Also labeling gmo's is a dumb idea.  Company's like kraft, kellogs, 
Mcdonald's etc. buy their corn and soybeans from more than one farmer.  The 
end result is that nearly all foods would have a label,whether they contain 
gmo's or not, costing the consumers more money with no result in lowering 
gmo's.  If some companies do choose to not use gmo's the prices of their 
food goes way up and so does the price of corn.since bt corn has a higher 
yield.  If you live in America you've been eating gmo's for nearly 20 
years.  You eat gmo's everyday, they are in nearly all processed food. 
 They aren't harmful.  But labeling them would be.  It would starve 
thousands who currently lives below the poverty line,
